input: Patient presents with eye symptoms including redness, swelling, and tearing. Symptoms began approximately 2 days ago after playing soccer.1. Diagnosis: Conjunctivitis (likely infectious) Justification: Redness and tearing are hallmark symptoms; although injury is possible, infectious conjunctivitis is common after exposure during sports activities, especially if the patient was exposed to other players or environmental agents.  2. Diagnosis: Corneal abrasion Justification: Recent trauma or foreign body during soccer can cause superficial corneal injury presenting with redness, tearing, and swelling.  3. Diagnosis: Allergic conjunctivitis Justification: Tearing and redness can result from allergic responses, especially if the patient has a history of allergies; however, onset after playing soccer is less typical unless environmental allergens are involved.  4. Diagnosis: Anterior uveitis Justification: Presents with redness, tearing, and possible swelling; often associated with pain and photophobia, but less sudden onset, making it a consideration.  5. Diagnosis: Traumatic hyphema Justification: Eye trauma during sports can lead to bleeding in the anterior chamber, causing swelling and redness; must consider if trauma was significant.  6. Diagnosis: Infectious keratitis Justification: An infection of the cornea post-trauma or exposure, presenting with redness and tearing; may be more common if there was foreign body or contact lens use.  7. Diagnosis: Episcleritis Justification: Causes localized redness and swelling, usually less painful, but can mimic conjunctivitis; often idiopathic or autoimmune.  8. Diagnosis: Subconjunctival hemorrhage Justification: Presents as localized bright red patch on the conjunctiva, often painless but can be prompted by trauma, including sports.  9. Diagnosis: Acute angle-closure glaucoma Justification: Presents with red eye and swelling, often associated with pain and visual disturbance; less likely if no pain or vision loss is mentioned.  10.
